statement.text: The lowest pressures achieved in laboratories are ~10⁻¹⁴ Pa (extreme ultra-high vacuum), corresponding to ~1 molecule per cubic meter. Intergalactic space has ~10⁻¹⁷ Pa. There is NO fundamental minimum pressure—it can approach zero. The Planck pressure (Pₚ ≈ 4.6 × 10¹¹³ Pa) is NOT a minimum—it's unimaginably enormous, the pressure inside a Planck-mass black hole.
statement.formal: Best vacuum: ~10⁻¹⁴ Pa; Intergalactic: ~10⁻¹⁷ Pa; Zero is theoretical limit; Planck: 4.6 × 10¹¹³ Pa

explanation.intuition: Pressure measures force per area from particle impacts. The lowest pressures correspond to fewest particles. In deep intergalactic space, there may be only ~1 atom per cubic meter, giving ~10⁻¹⁷ Pa. Perfect vacuum (0 Pa) is the theoretical limit. The Planck pressure is NOT minimum—it's the pressure where quantum gravity dominates, literally packing Planck energy into Planck volume.
explanation.key_insight: There is no minimum pressure because particle density can approach zero. Laboratory ultra-high vacuum reaches ~10⁻¹⁴ Pa using cryopumps, ion pumps, and bakeout. Space vacuum quality depends on distance from matter sources—intergalactic voids have the lowest natural pressures.

comparison_with_planck.interpretation: Planck pressure is the pressure inside a Planck-scale black hole. It's 10¹³⁰× larger than intergalactic pressure.

related.relationship: Planck pressure is NOT minimum—it's 10¹¹³ Pa

sources.citation: Jousten, K.: Handbook of Vacuum Technology
